intro: Polygonum sibiricum var. thomsonii, commonly known as Thomson's knotweed, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Polygonaceae family, characterized by its distinctive nodes and hollow stems. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, clustered flowers are usually pink or reddish, appearing in late summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats.
